Poitier‚Äôs legacy will live on, and continue to inspire millions of people here in America, in the Bahamas and the Caribbean, and around the world. A life well lived.

In 2002, Poitier won an Honorary Academy Award for overall contribution to cinema. The same year, Denzel Washington became the second Black man to win Best Actor. He said "40 years I've been chasing Sidney...I'll always be following in your footsteps." http://pbs.twimg.com/ext_tw_video_thumb/1479481953124597765/pu/img/Wq82LPqqr9CYpZ4a.jpg https://video.twimg.com/ext_tw_video/1479481953124597765/pu/vid/376x270/HNTvhOG76CLdzmd6.mp4?tag=12

Poitier continued to dominate at the box office and take home awards and nominations. In Guess Who's Coming to Dinner, he played a man in an interracial relationship, something that was still illegal in 17 states until just six months before the film's release.

As @MarkHarrisNYC wrote, Poitier "was well aware that...his win would be used to sell a preposterous falsehood...that the movie industry had solved its race problem." Wrote Poitier, "I knew we hadn't 'overcome' because I was still the only one."

He won his Best Actor Academy Award in 1963 for Lilies of the Field, an inspiring moment for millions of people. It was, and remains, a stunning accomplishment. But it was not the end of the struggle.
RT @HomelandGOP RT if you agree. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FIgbfUkXsAUkY5Z.jpg

In 1959 and 1961, he starred in A Raisin in the Sun, the first Broadway play written by a Black woman (Lorraine Hansberry) and first with a Black director (Lloyd Richards). The story, depicting Black life, "changed American theater forever."

In 1958, he became the first Black actor nominated for the Best Actor Academy Award, for his role in The Defiant Ones. He was also nominated for a Golden Globe, and won awards in Britain and Berlin the same year.

Sidney Poitier was a legend and inspiration. Born in Miami to Bahamian parents, his stunning stage and screen career was a powerful story of Black success, breaking barriers & challenging assumptions. He will be deeply missed, but his legacy will live on forever. Rest in peace. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FIgxIFiXIAAEChx.jpg
